articles.headline: Battle Looms Over Huge Costs of Public Pensions
articles.snippet: State governments have promised more in benefits than they have in their pension plans, leading to battles over who should pay to fill the gap.
articles.abstract: State governments have promised more in benefits than they have in their pension plans, leading to battles over who should pay to fill the gap.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s a class war coming to the world of government pensions.

articles.headline: Chrysler Dealers Find Barriers to Re-entry
articles.snippet: Former Chrysler dealers who won arbitration rulings said the automaker was refusing to extend a welcoming hand.
articles.abstract: Former Chrysler dealers who won arbitration rulings said the automaker was refusing to extend a welcoming hand.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a year of fighting Chrysler’s decision to cast aside his dealership, Jim Bickford expected to be back running Westminster Dodge, the only Chrysler franchise in Boston.

articles.headline: H.P. Ousts Chief for Hiding Payments to Friend
articles.snippet: Mark V. Hurd, who turned Hewlett-Packard into the world’s largest technology company, was found to have misused company funds.
articles.abstract: Mark V. Hurd, who turned Hewlett-Packard into the world’s largest technology company, was found to have misused company funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark V. Hurd, who turned Hewlett-Packard into the world’s largest technology company on the back of fierce fiscal discipline, has been ousted from his post for the lowliest of corporate offenses  fudging his expenses.

articles.headline: Greenspan Calls for Repeal of All the Bush Tax Cuts
articles.snippet: The former chairman of the Federal Reserve said keeping the cuts would drive up borrowing costs and could lead to another financial crisis.
articles.abstract: The former chairman of the Federal Reserve said keeping the cuts would drive up borrowing costs and could lead to another financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was not enough, it seems, for Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman and a self-described lifelong Republican libertarian, to call for stringent government regulation of giant banks, as he did a few months ago.

articles.headline: Watergate Becomes Sore Point at Nixon Library
articles.snippet: Loyalists argue that a Watergate exhibit at the museum is unfair and distorted.
articles.abstract: Loyalists argue that a Watergate exhibit at the museum is unfair and distorted.
articles.lead_paragraph: YORBA LINDA, Calif.  The sign at the entrance to the largest exhibition room devoted to a single subject at the Nixon Presidential Library and Museum reads “Watergate.” But on Friday, the exhibit was nearly empty, dominated by a 30-foot blank slate of a wall that is testimony to a new battle set off by this still-polarizing former president: how to mark the scandal that forced him from office 36 years ago.

articles.headline: A Man With Muffin Secrets, but No Job With Them
articles.snippet: To protect its recipe, the maker of Thomas’ English muffins has gone to court to prevent an executive from working for a rival.
articles.abstract: To protect its recipe, the maker of Thomas’ English muffins has gone to court to prevent an executive from working for a rival.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bite into a Thomas’ English muffin and, it turns out, you are about to swallow one of the most closely guarded secrets in the world of baking.

articles.headline: No Wheat Shortage, but Prices May Rise
articles.snippet: Russia’s drought and ban on exporting wheat have pushed prices higher, but a strong global supply should soften the blow.
articles.abstract: Russia’s drought and ban on exporting wheat have pushed prices higher, but a strong global supply should soften the blow.
articles.lead_paragraph: The price of wheat had been falling since the last great spike in 2008, but in April, Guy Lapointe seeded 2,200 acres of hard red spring wheat anyway on his rolling land in Alberta.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: A.I.G. in Talks to Pay U.S. Debt, Chief Says
articles.snippet: The American International Group has begun talks with the federal government over how to finish repaying its $130 billion taxpayer-financed bailout, its chief executive said on Friday.
articles.abstract: The American International Group has begun talks with the federal government over how to finish repaying its $130 billion taxpayer-financed bailout, its chief executive said on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American International Group has begun talks with the federal government over how to finish repaying its $130 billion taxpayer-financed bailout, its chief executive said on Friday.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Gunmen Kill Medical Aid Workers in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Members of a team that included six Americans, a Briton, a German and four Afghans were shot during an expedition to bring eye care and other services to remote areas.
articles.abstract: Members of a team that included six Americans, a Briton, a German and four Afghans were shot during an expedition to bring eye care and other services to remote areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Their last meal was a picnic in the forest in the Sharrun Valley, high in the Hindu Kush mountains of northern Afghanistan.

articles.headline: Republicans Seek Democratic Seats on McCain Turf
articles.snippet: In their bid to recapture the House, Republicans hope to mine Democratic seats from districts that picked John McCain over Barack Obama in the last presidential race.
articles.abstract: In their bid to recapture the House, Republicans hope to mine Democratic seats from districts that picked John McCain over Barack Obama in the last presidential race.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEDINA, Ohio — Of all the veins Republicans hope to mine to win seats they need to recapture the House, one may be particularly rich: Democratic seats from districts that picked John McCain over Barack Obama in the last presidential race.

articles.headline: Finding New Life (and Profit) in Doomed Trees
articles.snippet: A four-year-old business in Seattle is beating the recessionary odds by building furniture from trees doomed by development, disease or storms.
articles.abstract: A four-year-old business in Seattle is beating the recessionary odds by building furniture from trees doomed by development, disease or storms.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE

articles.headline: Housing Policy’s Third Rail
articles.snippet: What we may hear about fixing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac before the elections is a lot of sound and fury. But intelligent discussion is needed.
articles.abstract: What we may hear about fixing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac before the elections is a lot of sound and fury. But intelligent discussion is needed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHILE Congress toiled on the financial overhaul last spring, precious little was said about Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage finance companies that collapsed spectacularly two years ago.

articles.headline: But Will It Make You Happy?
articles.snippet: How you spend has a greater effect on your happiness than how much you spend, researchers say.
articles.abstract: How you spend has a greater effect on your happiness than how much you spend, researchers say.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHE had so much.

articles.headline: Minerals Service Had a Mandate to Produce Results
articles.snippet: The Minerals Management Service has been ridiculed as a pawn of the oil industry it was meant to oversee, and the Gulf Coast office has drawn particular scorn.
articles.abstract: The Minerals Management Service has been ridiculed as a pawn of the oil industry it was meant to oversee, and the Gulf Coast office has drawn particular scorn.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  On March 5, 1997, an obscure federal official with a puckish grin entered a hotel ballroom here and greeted 1,000 jittery oilmen on what would prove a landmark day.

articles.headline: Across Nation, Mosque Projects Meet Opposition
articles.snippet: Heated conflicts have broken out in communities where mosques are proposed near far less hallowed locations than ground zero.
articles.abstract: Heated conflicts have broken out in communities where mosques are proposed near far less hallowed locations than ground zero.
articles.lead_paragraph: While a high-profile battle rages over a mosque near ground zero in Manhattan, heated confrontations have also broken out in communities across the country where mosques are proposed for far less hallowed locations.

articles.headline: Boss’s Stumble May Also Trip Hewlett-Packard
articles.snippet: Mark V. Hurd’s ouster after a relationship with Jodie Fisher has put an unsavory end to one of the most notable executive turns in American business history.
articles.abstract: Mark V. Hurd’s ouster after a relationship with Jodie Fisher has put an unsavory end to one of the most notable executive turns in American business history.
articles.lead_paragraph: The events were billed as C.E.O. executive summit meetings, exclusive gatherings, often lasting several days, where Hewlett-Packard officials wooed top customers. When Mark V. Hurd, H.P.’s chief, appeared at them, he sometimes relied on Jodie Fisher, a 50-year-old former reality television contestant turned H.P. marketing consultant, who would introduce him to customers and keep him company.

articles.headline: India Asks, Should Food Be a Right for the Poor?
articles.snippet: India is debating whether to dismantle an inefficient, decades-old food distribution system and try something radical.
articles.abstract: India is debating whether to dismantle an inefficient, decades-old food distribution system and try something radical.
articles.lead_paragraph: JHABUA, India  Inside the drab district hospital, where dogs patter down the corridors, sniffing for food, Ratan Bhuria’s children are curled together in the malnutrition ward, hovering at the edge of starvation. His daughter, Nani, is 4 and weighs 20 pounds. His son, Jogdiya, is 2 and weighs only eight.

articles.headline: BlackBerry Security Stance Sows Anxiety
articles.snippet: Some countries want the same access to BlackBerry’s encrypted services that they think is already given to the United States and other industrialized democracies.
articles.abstract: Some countries want the same access to BlackBerry’s encrypted services that they think is already given to the United States and other industrialized democracies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 2008 terrorist attacks in Mumbai heightened concerns in India over the government’s inability to eavesdrop on encrypted communications. In the United Arab Emirates, similar concerns escalated this year after a Palestinian operative was killed in a hotel in Dubai, possibly by a team from the Mossad, the Israeli intelligence agency.
articles.byline: By Miguel Helft and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: A Gamble on a Weekly That Paid Off
articles.snippet: New York magazine was a success for Bruce Wasserstein, offering Sidney Harman a rough blueprint for reviving Newsweek.
articles.abstract: New York magazine was a success for Bruce Wasserstein, offering Sidney Harman a rough blueprint for reviving Newsweek.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let me get this straight: A very rich guy buys a financially and editorially beleaguered weekly magazine, saying he wants to preserve an important journalistic asset. That will never work, right?

articles.headline: The Economist Tends Its Sophisticate Garden
articles.snippet: The Economist, a bible of world news with a heavy dose of business, seeks readers who see themselves moving up in the world.
articles.abstract: The Economist, a bible of world news with a heavy dose of business, seeks readers who see themselves moving up in the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: Its fire-engine-red logo peeks out of fashionable handbags and from the back pockets of designer jeans. Bankers read it in first-class seats. Hipsters read it on the subway on their way to work.

articles.headline: Investor Appetite for Bonds in a Tepid Recovery Weighs on Rates
articles.snippet: Rates of all sorts  mortgage, Treasury, certificates of deposit  are being driven lower, and not by the Fed.
articles.abstract: Rates of all sorts  mortgage, Treasury, certificates of deposit  are being driven lower, and not by the Fed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just how low can interest rates go?

articles.headline: A Times Square Aura for Pop-Tarts
articles.snippet: Pop-Tarts is joining brands like M&M’s and Hershey in Times Square, where the focus is often less about sales than marketing and visibility.
articles.abstract: Pop-Tarts is joining brands like M&M’s and Hershey in Times Square, where the focus is often less about sales than marketing and visibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: Poor Pop-Tarts.

articles.headline: After Drought, Hope for Shows Made for Web
articles.snippet: Money is trickling back into the professional Internet video industry, helped by branded entertainment deals and venture capital firms.
articles.abstract: Money is trickling back into the professional Internet video industry, helped by branded entertainment deals and venture capital firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Illeana Douglas, long active in independent film, wanted to make a show about a Hollywood actress who becomes a cog in a blue-collar wheel, she turned to the Web and to an unusual ally, Ikea.

articles.headline: Early Struggles of Soldier Charged in Leak Case
articles.snippet: People who know Pfc. Bradley Manning wonder whether his desperation for acceptance may have led him to disclose a trove of government secrets.
articles.abstract: People who know Pfc. Bradley Manning wonder whether his desperation for acceptance may have led him to disclose a trove of government secrets.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  He spent part of his childhood with his father in the arid plains of central Oklahoma, where classmates made fun of him for being a geek. He spent another part with his mother in a small, remote corner of southwest Wales, where classmates made fun of him for being gay.

articles.headline: Students Spared Amid an Increase in Deportations
articles.snippet: The Obama administration, while deporting a record number of immigrants convicted of crimes, is sparing students who came without papers as children.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration, while deporting a record number of immigrants convicted of crimes, is sparing students who came without papers as children.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration, while deporting a record number of immigrants convicted of crimes, is sparing one group of illegal immigrants from expulsion: students who came to the United States without papers when they were children.

articles.headline: In Crackdown on Energy Use, China to Shut 2,000 Factories
articles.snippet: The government said it hoped to improve energy efficiency by closing some steel mills, cement works and other energy-intensive factories.
articles.abstract: The government said it hoped to improve energy efficiency by closing some steel mills, cement works and other energy-intensive factories.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  Earlier this summer, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China promised to use an “iron hand” to improve his country’s energy efficiency, and a growing number of businesses are now discovering that it feels like a fist.
